thread.title: Kenya: Firm Denies UN Claim On Ship
thread.title_full: Kenya: Firm Denies UN Claim On Ship

title: Kenya: Firm Denies UN Claim On Ship
text:
Kenya: Nations Begin New 15-Year Journey With Adoption of SDGs 
Revelations that firearms seized from a ship at the Mombasa port last week were declared in the bill of lading but not in the manifest by the UN contradict that of the shipping company. 
The world body on Thursday said a request was sent by the shipment contractor to the ship's agent in Mombasa to amend the manifest but as this was not possible, a declaration of the weapons accompanying the military vehicles was attached. 
The statement from UN Secretary-General Ban Ki- moon's spokesperson said the weapons were legitimate and declared cargo. 
However, Höegh Autoliners said the weapons were not declared to them at the time the cargo was loaded. 
"The fact that weapons were in the vehicles is in violation with our terms of transportation, which clearly states that no arms or ammunition are accepted for shipment," read the statement on their website. 
Höegh Transporter is currently berthed at Mombasa while its 20 crew, including Chinese and a Norwegian captain, await to be charged with transporting unlicensed ammunitions. 
The firearms included American made M60 machine guns. The crew, engineers, cooks, master officer and the captain will be arraigned at the Mombasa Law Courts. 
"They will be charged depending on how the magistrate advises. Transporting of firearms without a manifest is among charges they may face. The magistrate may also order the ship's destruction," added a senior police officer. 
The UN vehicles will remain at the port until they are cleared, added the officer. 
On Thursday, Inspector-General of Police Joseph Boinnet said: "The ship was doing normal deliveries but we got wind it was carrying items that were not authorised in this country. That is why it was seized and searched." 
The UN denied that drugs were found on the ship. Mr Boinnet said the white powder had been sent to the government chemist. 
The vessel had carried 257 Tata vehicles for the UN from Mumbai, India destined for peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo. 
"During a cargo inspection, which has taken place over the last few days in Mombasa, Kenyan authorities discovered weapons not declared in the cargo manifest, inside some of the UN vehicles. It is our understanding that these weapons belong to the UN vehicles in which they were found, and were for use by the UN during their peacekeeping mission," read the statement. 
The shipment company said they had no information to ascertain whether the white substance found were drugs. Kenya
